message.content:
Explore all guide files in src/data/guides/ and find every product ID referenced. Then verify each one exists in products-registry.ts.

1. Read all guide files (*.ts) in src/data/guides/
2. Find all productIds arrays and products arrays in guide sections
3. List every unique product ID found
4. Check each against products-registry.ts to see if it exists
5. Report any missing product IDs that need to be added

Be thorough - check ALL guides including: mindset.ts, maintenance.ts, body-fat.ts, v-taper.ts, training.ts, core-neck.ts, cardio.ts, diet.ts, skincare.ts, stress-supplements.ts, dopamine-optimization.ts, and any others.

content.text:
I'll explore all guide files in `src/data/guides/` and verify that every product ID referenced exists in the products-registry.

Let me start by finding all guide files and then systematically checking product IDs.

1→/**
     2→ * Product Registry for Guides System
     3→ * 73 products with multi-region affiliate links and Ross-style taglines
     4→ * Categories: hygiene, grooming, skincare, miscellaneous, supplements, hair, beard, teeth, kbeauty, hormonal, surgery
     5→ */
     6→
     7→import { GuideProduct, ProductCategory } from '@/types/guides';
     8→import { buildAmazonUrl } from '@/lib/region';
     9→
    10→// ============================================
    11→// AMAZON ASIN MAPPING BY REGION
    12→// ============================================
    13→
    14→interface ProductASINs {
    15→  us?: string;
    16→  uk?: string;
    17→  de?: string;
    18→  fr?: string;
    19→  au?: string;
    20→}
    21→
    22→// Regions that have Amazon stores with ASINs
    23→type AmazonRegion = 'us' | 'uk' | 'de' | 'fr' | 'au';
    24→const AMAZON_REGIONS: AmazonRegion[] = ['us', 'uk', 'de', 'fr', 'au'];
    25→
    26→// Helper to build region links from ASINs
    27→function buildRegionLinks(asins: ProductASINs): Record<string, string> {
    28→  const links: Record<string, string> = {};
    29→
    30→  AMAZON_REGIONS.forEach(region => {
    31→    const asin = asins[region] || asins.us; // Fallback to US ASIN
    32→    if (asin) {
    33→      links[region] = buildAmazonUrl(asin, region);
    34→    }
    35→  });
    36→
    37→  // Asia uses US ASIN on amzn.asia domain
    38→  if (asins.us) {
    39→    links['asia'] = buildAmazonUrl(asins.us, 'asia');
    40→  }
    41→
    42→  return links;
    43→}
    44→

    46→// PRODUCT DATABASE (33 Products)

  1299→// ============================================
  1300→// HELPER FUNCTIONS

  1302→
  1303→/**
  1304→ * Product ID aliases for backwards compatibility
  1305→ * Maps shorthand IDs to full product IDs
  1306→ */
  1307→const PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES: Record<string, string> = {
  1308→  // Supplements
  1309→  ashwagandha: 'ashwagandha_ksm66',
  1310→  creatine: 'creatine_mono',
  1311→  omega_3: 'omega3_fish_oil',
  1312→  zinc: 'zinc_picolinate',
  1313→  // Add more as needed
  1314→};
  1315→
  1316→/**
  1317→ * Get product by ID (supports aliases)
  1318→ */
  1319→export function getGuideProductById(id: string): GuideProduct | undefined {
  1320→  // Resolve alias if it exists
  1321→  const resolvedId = PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES[id] || id;
  1322→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.find(p => p.id === resolvedId);
  1323→}
  1324→
  1325→/**
  1326→ * Get all products in a category
  1327→ */
  1328→export function getGuideProductsByCategory(category: ProductCategory): GuideProduct[] {
  1329→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
  1330→    .filter(p => p.category === category)
  1331→    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
  1332→}
  1333→
  1334→/**
  1335→ * Get all base stack products (essentials for everyone)
  1336→ */
  1337→export function getBaseStackProducts(): GuideProduct[] {
  1338→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
  1339→    .filter(p => p.isBaseStack)
  1340→    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
  1341→}
  1342→
  1343→/**
  1344→ * Get products by priority level
  1345→ */
  1346→export function getGuideProductsByPriority(priority: number): GuideProduct[] {
  1347→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.priority === priority);
  1348→}
  1349→
  1350→/**
  1351→ * Get all unique categories with product counts
  1352→ */
  1353→export function getProductCategories(): Array<{ category: ProductCategory; count: number }> {
  1354→  const categories: ProductCategory[] = [
  1355→    'hygiene',
  1356→    'grooming',
  1357→    'skincare',
  1358→    'miscellaneous',
  1359→    'supplements',
  1360→    'hair',
  1361→    'beard',
  1362→    'teeth',
  1363→    'kbeauty',
  1364→    'hormonal',
  1365→    'surgery',
  1366→  ];
  1367→
  1368→  return categories.map(category => ({
  1369→    category,
  1370→    count: GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.category === category).length,
  1371→  }));
  1372→}
  1373→
  1374→/**
  1375→ * Get products by array of IDs (preserves order)
  1376→ */
  1377→export function getGuideProductsByIds(ids: string[]): GuideProduct[] {
  1378→  return ids
  1379→    .map(id => getGuideProductById(id))
  1380→    .filter((p): p is GuideProduct => p !== undefined);
  1381→}
  1382→
  1383→/**
  1384→ * Search products by name or description
  1385→ */
  1386→export function searchGuideProducts(query: string): GuideProduct[] {
  1387→  const lowered = query.toLowerCase();
  1388→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p =>
  1389→    p.name.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1390→    p.description.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1391→    p.tagline.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1392→    (p.brand && p.brand.toLowerCase().includes(lowered))
  1393→  );
  1394→}
  1395→
  1396→/**
  1397→ * Get total product count
  1398→ */
  1399→export function getTotalProductCount(): number {
  1400→  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.length;

/**
 * Product Registry for Guides System
 * 73 products with multi-region affiliate links and Ross-style taglines
 * Categories: hygiene, grooming, skincare, miscellaneous, supplements, hair, beard, teeth, kbeauty, hormonal, surgery
 */

import { GuideProduct, ProductCategory } from '@/types/guides';
import { buildAmazonUrl } from '@/lib/region';

// ============================================
// AMAZON ASIN MAPPING BY REGION
// ============================================

interface ProductASINs {
  us?: string;
  uk?: string;
  de?: string;
  fr?: string;
  au?: string;
}

// Regions that have Amazon stores with ASINs
type AmazonRegion = 'us' | 'uk' | 'de' | 'fr' | 'au';
const AMAZON_REGIONS: AmazonRegion[] = ['us', 'uk', 'de', 'fr', 'au'];

// Helper to build region links from ASINs
function buildRegionLinks(asins: ProductASINs): Record<string, string> {
  const links: Record<string, string> = {};

  AMAZON_REGIONS.forEach(region => {
    const asin = asins[region] || asins.us; // Fallback to US ASIN
    if (asin) {
      links[region] = buildAmazonUrl(asin, region);
    }
  });

  // Asia uses US ASIN on amzn.asia domain
  if (asins.us) {
    links['asia'] = buildAmazonUrl(asins.us, 'asia');
  }

  return links;
}

// ============================================
// HELPER FUNCTIONS
// ============================================

/**
 * Product ID aliases for backwards compatibility
 * Maps shorthand IDs to full product IDs
 */
const PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES: Record<string, string> = {
  // Supplements
  ashwagandha: 'ashwagandha_ksm66',
  creatine: 'creatine_mono',
  omega_3: 'omega3_fish_oil',
  zinc: 'zinc_picolinate',
  // Add more as needed
};

/**
 * Get product by ID (supports aliases)
 */
export function getGuideProductById(id: string): GuideProduct | undefined {
  // Resolve alias if it exists
  const resolvedId = PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES[id] || id;
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.find(p => p.id === resolvedId);
}

/**
 * Get all products in a category
 */
export function getGuideProductsByCategory(category: ProductCategory): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
    .filter(p => p.category === category)
    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
}

/**
 * Get all base stack products (essentials for everyone)
 */
export function getBaseStackProducts(): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
    .filter(p => p.isBaseStack)
    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
}

/**
 * Get products by priority level
 */
export function getGuideProductsByPriority(priority: number): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.priority === priority);
}

/**
 * Get all unique categories with product counts
 */
export function getProductCategories(): Array<{ category: ProductCategory; count: number }> {
  const categories: ProductCategory[] = [
    'hygiene',
    'grooming',
    'skincare',
    'miscellaneous',
    'supplements',
    'hair',
    'beard',
    'teeth',
    'kbeauty',
    'hormonal',
    'surgery',
  ];

  return categories.map(category => ({
    category,
    count: GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.category === category).length,
  }));
}

/**
 * Get products by array of IDs (preserves order)
 */
export function getGuideProductsByIds(ids: string[]): GuideProduct[] {
  return ids
    .map(id => getGuideProductById(id))
    .filter((p): p is GuideProduct => p !== undefined);
}

/**
 * Search products by name or description
 */
export function searchGuideProducts(query: string): GuideProduct[] {
  const lowered = query.toLowerCase();
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p =>
    p.name.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    p.description.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    p.tagline.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    (p.brand && p.brand.toLowerCase().includes(lowered))
  );
}

/**
 * Get total product count
 */
export function getTotalProductCount(): number {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.length;
}

/**
 * Get category display info
 */
export function getCategoryDisplayInfo(category: ProductCategory): {
  name: string;
  icon: string;
  description: string;
} {
  const info: Record<ProductCategory, { name: string; icon: string; description: string }> = {
    hygiene: {
      name: 'Hygiene',
      icon: 'Sparkles',
      description: 'Fundamentals of not repelling people',
    },
    grooming: {
      name: 'Grooming',
      icon: 'Scissors',
      description: 'Tools for precision face maintenance',
    },
    skincare: {
      name: 'Skincare',
      icon: 'Droplet',
      description: 'Your skin is your face. Treat it right.',
    },
    miscellaneous: {
      name: 'Miscellaneous',
      icon: 'Package',
      description: 'The supporting cast of your glow-up',
    },
    supplements: {
      name: 'Supplements',
      icon: 'Pill',
      description: 'Fill the gaps your diet is missing',
    },
    hair: {
      name: 'Hair',
      icon: 'Wind',
      description: 'The Big 3 and beyond—save what you have',
    },
    beard: {
      name: 'Beard',
      icon: 'User',
      description: 'Grow it, groom it, own it',
    },
    teeth: {
      name: 'Teeth',
      icon: 'Smile',
      description: 'Your smile is worth more than you think',
    },
    kbeauty: {
      name: 'K-Beauty',
      icon: 'Sparkle',
      description: 'Glass skin protocols from Seoul',
    },
    hormonal: {
      name: 'Hormonal',
      icon: 'Heart',
      description: 'PCOS, hormonal acne, and balance',
    },
    surgery: {
      name: 'Surgery',
      icon: 'Stethoscope',
      description: 'Post-op recovery essentials',
    },
  };

  return info[category];
}

/**
 * Mindset & Beginner Mistakes Guide
 * Humor Level: High (30%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const mindsetGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'mindset',
  slug: 'mindset-mistakes',
  title: 'Mindset & Beginner Mistakes',
  subtitle: "The cope stops here",
  description: "Before you spend a dime, fix the mental game. Most guys sabotage themselves before they even start.",
  icon: 'Brain',
  humorLevel: 'high',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 1,
  tags: ['mindset', 'beginners', 'fundamentals'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat'],
  productIds: [],
  forumCategory: 'anxiety',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'mindset-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1507003211169-0a1dd7228f2d?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Focused mindset and determination',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Real Talk',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're here because you want to look better. Good. That's the first step.

But here's what nobody tells you: **most guys fail not because they don't know what to do, but because their mindset is cooked from day one.**

They're either:
- Paralyzed by analysis (reading guides instead of taking action)
- Expecting overnight results (then quitting after 2 weeks)
- Comparing themselves to genetic outliers (and feeling defeated)
- Looking for shortcuts (spoiler: there aren't any)

This guide is about fixing that before you waste months spinning your wheels.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'mindset-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1552674605-db6ffd4facb5?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Man focused on goals',
          caption: 'The mindset game starts before everything else',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'level-up-gif',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/H9l0FtwC2hA3V7Bj5H/giphy.gif',
          alt: 'Level Up pixel animation',
          caption: 'Time to level up',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-1-perfectionism',
      title: 'Mistake #1: Waiting for the "Perfect" Plan',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You've bookmarked 47 articles. You've saved 200 Instagram posts. You've downloaded 12 PDFs. You've done exactly **zero** actual work.

**This ain't it, chief.**

The perfect routine doesn't exist. There's no secret combination of products and exercises that will unlock chad-tier genetics. There's just consistent effort over time.

Here's the brutal truth: a mediocre plan executed consistently beats a perfect plan you never start.

**Action Step:** Pick ONE thing from this app to improve. Just one. Do it for 30 days before adding anything else.`,
      tips: [
        'Done is better than perfect',
        'Consistency beats intensity every single time',
        'Start before you feel ready'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'perfectionism-trap',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1484480974693-6ca0a78fb36b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Planning and action',
          caption: 'Stop planning, start doing',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-2-timeline',
      title: 'Mistake #2: Expecting Fast Results',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `You started mewing yesterday and you're checking your jawline in the mirror this morning. Bro.

Real change takes **months to years**, depending on what you're working on:

| Change | Timeline |
|--------|----------|
| Better skin (routine) | 6-12 weeks |
| Body recomposition | 3-6 months |
| Posture improvement | 3-6 months |
| Hair regrowth (minox) | 6-12 months |
| Mewing (adults) | 1-2+ years |

**The guys who win are the ones who forget about results and just lock in on the process.**

Think about it: if you had started 6 months ago, you'd already be there. You didn't. So start now and stop checking daily.`,
      warnings: [
        'Taking progress photos daily will drive you insane',
        'Monthly or bi-monthly comparison photos are enough'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-3-comparison',
      title: 'Mistake #3: Comparing to Genetic Outliers',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're comparing yourself to guys who:
- Won the genetic lottery
- Have professional lighting in every photo
- Are on gear and won't admit it
- Use filters/editing
- Got surgery and claim "just mewing bro"

**This is NPC behavior.**

Here's a better frame: you're not trying to become someone else. You're trying to mog your past self. That's it.

Your only competition is the guy you were 6 months ago. If he'd be jealous of where you are now, you're winning.`,
      tips: [
        'Mog your past self, not strangers on the internet',
        'Unfollow accounts that make you feel like garbage',
        'Follow for information, not comparison'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-4-shortcuts',
      title: 'Mistake #4: Looking for Shortcuts',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `There are no shortcuts. There are no hacks. There is no "one weird trick."

The internet is full of people trying to sell you things you don't need:
- Miracle supplements that do nothing
- Expensive gadgets that collect dust
- "Secret" techniques that are just repackaged basics

**Here's what actually works:**
1. Sleep 7-9 hours
2. Eat enough protein
3. Lift weights
4. Use sunscreen
5. Stay lean
6. Groom yourself

That's 90% of it. Everything else is optimization on top of this foundation. If you're not doing these six things consistently, nothing else matters.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-5-all-or-nothing',
      title: 'Mistake #5: All-or-Nothing Thinking',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `You miss one gym session and think "welp, the whole week is ruined."
You eat one bad meal and say "might as well order pizza for the rest of the week."
You skip your skincare once and abandon the routine entirely.

**This is self-sabotage with extra steps.**

Progress isn't linear. Life happens. The goal isn't perfection—it's **consistency over time**.

Missing one day means nothing. Missing one day, then letting it spiral into one week, then one month? That's the killer.

**The rule:** If you miss, just get back on track the next opportunity. No guilt, no drama. Just reset and continue.`,
      tips: [
        'One bad day is noise. One bad month is a pattern.',
        "Never miss twice in a row—that's the real rule",
        'Lower the bar if needed, but show up'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-6-money-before-basics',
      title: 'Mistake #6: Spending Money Before Basics',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're researching jaw implants but you're at 22% body fat.
You want Botox but you've never worn sunscreen.
You're considering hair transplants but you sleep 5 hours a night.

**You're skipping chapters, my guy.**

Here's the priority order:
1. **Free tier:** Sleep, hydration, basic hygiene, mewing, posture
2. **Low cost ($20-50/mo):** Gym, skincare basics, grooming tools
3. **Medium cost ($50-200/mo):** Supplements, better products, minoxidil
4. **High cost ($500+):** Treatments, procedures, surgery

Don't level skip. The expensive stuff doesn't work if the foundation is garbage.

Surgery on a 25% body fat face is like putting a spoiler on a Honda Civic. Fix the car first.`,
      warnings: [
        "Surgery doesn't fix lifestyle problems",
        'Get to 12% body fat before considering facial procedures'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-real-strategy',
      title: 'The Actual Strategy That Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's what the successful guys do:

**1. Accept the timeline**
You're playing a 1-2 year game minimum. Accept that now or quit.

**2. Build systems, not goals**
"I want a better jawline" is a goal. "I chew mastic gum for 20 minutes after every meal" is a system. Systems win.

**3. Track ruthlessly**
Take monthly photos. Same lighting, same angle, same expression. This is the only objective measure.

**4. Iterate slowly**
Add one new thing every 4-6 weeks. Not five things at once. You need to know what's actually working.

**5. Focus on the 80/20**
20% of actions produce 80% of results. For most guys:
- Getting lean (diet + exercise)
- Skincare (cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen)
- Grooming (hair, brows, facial hair)

**Nail these before anything else.**`,
      tips: [
        'Progress compounds over time',
        'Small daily actions beat occasional big efforts',
        'Document everything so you can see the change'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'strategy-visual',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1434596922112-19c563067271?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Progress and tracking',
          caption: 'Track ruthlessly, iterate slowly',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'closing',
      title: 'Lock In',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `The cope stops here. No more excuses. No more "I'll start Monday." No more blaming genetics.

You have all the information you need. This app, this guide, these tools—they're more than enough.

The only question is whether you're actually going to do the work or just read about it and go back to whatever you were doing before.

**Your move.**

Mog your past self. That's the whole game.`,
    },
  ],
};

      title: 'Hair Maintenance for Thinning Hair',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you're noticing recession or thinning, you've got two choices: treat it or accept it. There's no middle ground of denial.

**Recognize the Signs Early:**
- Hairline moving back at temples (receding)
- Crown getting thinner (you can't see it, but others can)
- More hair in the drain/pillow
- Scalp visible under bright lights

**The Treatment Stack (The "Big 3"):**

| Treatment | What It Does | Cost |
|-----------|--------------|------|
| **Minoxidil 5%** | Stimulates follicles, extends growth phase | $20-40/6 months |
| **Finasteride 1mg** | Blocks DHT, stops progression | $10-30/month |
| **Ketoconazole Shampoo** | Anti-inflammatory, mild DHT blocker | $15/bottle |

**Timeline:**
- Months 1-3: Possible shedding (normal, it's working)
- Months 4-6: Stabilization, slowed loss
- Months 6-12: Regrowth begins for responders
- Year 1+: Maintenance mode

**The Decision:**
If you're going to treat, start NOW. The earlier you start, the more hair you save. Once a follicle is dead, it's gone.

**The Alternative:**
If treatment isn't for you, own the look:
- Buzz it short or shave clean
- Grow a beard if you can (bald + beard is a classic look)
- Get lean—face definition matters more when hair is gone
- Confidence > coping

We'll have a full hair loss guide coming soon. For now, don't wait—decide early.`,
      tips: [
        'Minoxidil can cause initial shedding—this is normal and temporary',
        'Apply minoxidil to DRY scalp, not wet',
        'Finasteride side effects are rare (1-2%) but discuss with doctor'
      ],
      warnings: [
        "Don't waste money on 'hair growth' supplements—most don't work",
        "Comb-overs fool nobody. Either treat it or embrace it."
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'beard-maintenance',
      title: 'Beard Maintenance & Growth',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Whether you're trying to grow a beard or maintain one, here's what actually matters:

**If You Can Grow One:**

**Stubble (1-5mm):**
- Trim every 2-3 days
- This is often the most attractive option for most faces
- Clean neckline 2 fingers above Adam's apple
- Edge cheek line naturally

**Short Beard (5-10mm):**
- Trim weekly with guard
- Use beard oil after showering
- Keep edges sharp

**Full Beard (10mm+):**
- Wash with beard shampoo
- Apply beard oil or balm daily
- Comb/brush to train direction
- Trim every 1-2 weeks for shape
- Consider a barber for initial shaping

**If You CAN'T Grow One (Yet):**

The Minoxidil beard protocol works for many guys:
1. Apply minoxidil 5% to cheeks 2x daily
2. Wait 6-24 months (yes, it takes time)
3. Vellus hairs → Terminal hairs
4. Once terminal, effects are permanent
5. Add dermarolling 0.5mm weekly for better absorption

**Important:** This is off-label use. Results vary. Most guys see significant improvement, but genetics still matter.

**Patchy Beard Solutions:**
- Let it grow longer—length hides patches
- Strategic trimming to balance density
- Focus on stubble length if very patchy
- Some patches fill in over time (give it 3-6 months)

We'll have a full beard growth guide with protocols coming soon.`,
      tips: [
        'Beard growth often improves into your 30s',
        'Minoxidil on beard can cause dryness—moisturize',
        "Don't compare your beard at 22 to someone's at 32"
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'checklist',
      title: 'The Weekly Checklist',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Print this. Put it on your bathroom mirror. No excuses.

**Daily:**
- [ ] Brush teeth (AM + PM)
- [ ] Floss
- [ ] Tongue scrape
- [ ] Apply lip balm
- [ ] Deodorant (night)
- [ ] Style hair
- [ ] Check mirror before leaving

**Weekly (Sunday Reset):**
- [ ] Trim nose/ear hair
- [ ] Eyebrow cleanup
- [ ] Facial hair maintenance
- [ ] Nail trim
- [ ] Deep clean ears

**Monthly:**
- [ ] Haircut
- [ ] Replace toothbrush head
- [ ] Inventory grooming supplies

**This is the baseline.** This is what separates "that guy takes care of himself" from "what's that smell?"

Lock in.`,
    },
  ],
};

   106→      content: `Fat distribution is genetic, but there's a general pattern:
   107→
   108→---

   157→      content: `Most methods are garbage. Here's the hierarchy:

   203→

   209→
   210→That's it. There's no metabolic magic. No foods that "burn fat." No supplements that override physics.

   236→**The Reality:** Most guys try to cut too fast, lose muscle, feel like death, and rebound. Don't be that guy.`,

   247→      content: `When cutting, protein is king. Everything else is secondary.

   249→---
   250→

   279→| **TOTAL** | | **180g** |
   280→
   281→If you're consistently under on protein, you're going to lose muscle and end up looking worse at the same weight.`,
   282→      products: ['creatine_mono'],

   284→    {
   285→      id: 'water-and-bloat',
   286→      title: 'Water Weight and Facial Bloat',

   288→      content: `You're not drinking enough water. Yes, you.

   291→
   292→---
   293→
   294→## The Paradox

   299→
   300→## The Protocol
   301→
   302→| Bodyweight | Daily Water Target |

   304→| 150 lbs | 75 oz (2.2L) |
   305→| 180 lbs | 90 oz (2.7L) |
   306→| 200 lbs | 100 oz (3L) |
   307→| 220 lbs | 110 oz (3.3L) |
   308→
   309→Add more if training or sweating.
   310→
   311→---
   312→
   313→## What Causes Facial Bloat
   314→
   315→| Cause | Effect | Fix |
   316→|-------|--------|-----|
   317→| **Sodium** | High salt = water retention | Keep moderate, not zero |
   318→| **Alcohol** | Dehydrates, then overcompensates | Limit or eliminate |

   321→| **Dehydration** | Counter-intuitive but true | Drink more water |
   322→
   323→---
   324→
   325→## The Morning Difference
   326→

   328→
   329→You're slightly dehydrated after 8 hours without water. This is why fighters cut water weight—it makes a visible difference.

   332→      products: ['water_jug'],
   333→      tips: [

   338→      media: [

   340→          id: 'bloat-comparison',

   349→    {
   350→      id: 'timeline',
   351→      title: 'Realistic Cutting Timeline',
   352→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   353→      content: `Let's set realistic expectations:
   354→
   355→---
   356→
   357→## Starting Point: 20% Body Fat (180lb guy)
   358→
   359→- **Goal:** 12% body fat
   360→- **Fat to lose:** ~15 lbs
   361→- **Timeline:** 10-15 weeks (doing it right)
   362→
   363→---
   364→
   365→## Week by Week Progress
   366→
   367→| Weeks | What Happens | What You See |
   368→|-------|--------------|--------------|
   369→| **1-2** | Water weight drops | Scale moves fast, exciting |
   370→| **3-6** | Steady fat loss | Starting to see changes |
   371→| **7-10** | Face starts tightening | Jaw appearing, cheekbones hint |
   372→| **11-15** | Final stubborn fat burns | Face pops, transformation complete |
   373→
   374→---
   375→
   376→## The Trap
   377→
   378→Weeks 6-10 are where most guys quit.
   379→
   380→Scale slows, you don't see daily changes, and pizza sounds really good.
   381→
   382→## The Reality
   383→
   384→> Fat loss in the face often happens in the **final phase**.
   385→
   386→You might look the same for weeks, then suddenly *"damn, there's my jawline."*
   387→
   388→Be patient. Trust the deficit. Don't quit in the middle of the transformation.`,
   389→      warnings: [

   391→        'Take weekly photos in the same conditions for accurate comparison',
   392→      ],
   393→      media: [
   394→        {
   395→          id: 'timeline-progress',
   396→          type: 'image',
   397→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1517836357463-d25dfeac3438?w=800&q=80',
   398→          alt: 'Visual timeline of fitness progress',
   399→          caption: '12-week transformation: patience is key',
   400→          placement: 'inline',
   401→        },
   402→      ],
   403→    },
   404→    {
   405→      id: 'maintaining',
   406→      title: 'Maintaining Lean (The Hard Part)',
   407→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   408→      content: `Getting lean is one thing. Staying lean is another.
   409→
   410→---
   411→
   412→## Why Maintenance Is Hard
   413→
   414→- Hunger hormones increase after cutting
   415→- Metabolism adapts (slightly) to lower calories
   416→- One vacation can undo weeks of progress
   417→- Life happens
   418→
   419→## The Strategy
   420→
   421→1. **Reverse diet** — Slowly increase calories after cutting
   422→2. **Stay active** — NEAT (daily movement) matters as much as gym
   423→3. **Keep tracking** — At least loosely, forever
   424→4. **Set a ceiling** — "I never go above 15%" as a rule
   425→
   426→---
   427→
   428→## The Buffer Zone
   429→
   430→Cutting to 11% then maintaining at 13% is easier than trying to stay at 11% year-round.
   431→
   432→Give yourself a 2-3% buffer for life fluctuations.
   433→
   434→## The Long Game
   435→
   436→> Most guys yo-yo because they treat cutting as temporary.
   437→
   438→Make leanness part of your identity, not a phase.`,
   439→    },
   440→    {
   441→      id: 'face-fat-timeline',
   442→      title: 'Face Fat Timeline by Body Fat %',
   443→      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   444→      content: `When does the face actually lean out? Here's the brutal truth by body fat percentage:
   445→
   446→**The Face Fat Timeline:**
   447→
   448→| Body Fat % | Face Status | What You See |
   449→|------------|-------------|--------------|
   450→| **25%+** | Maximum bloat | Round face, double chin likely, jaw completely hidden |
   451→| **22-25%** | Soft face | Face is round, no definition, chipmunk mode |
   452→| **18-22%** | Still soft | Jaw exists but is soft, some face fat visible |
   453→| **15-18%** | Improving | Jaw becoming defined, some cheek fat remaining |
   454→| **12-15%** | Good definition | Jaw pops, cheekbones starting to show, face leaning out |
   455→| **10-12%** | Excellent | Hollow cheeks appearing, strong jaw, model tier face |
   456→| **8-10%** | Maximum definition | Chiseled, veins in face possible, not sustainable |
   457→
   458→**The Critical Threshold:**
   459→For most men, facial definition really kicks in between **12-15%**. If you're 18% and wondering why your face still looks soft despite visible abs in good lighting—this is why.
   460→
   461→**Why Your Face Is Last:**
   462→Your body prioritizes fat storage in the face and midsection for protection and hormone regulation. These are the "safe" areas to store reserves. When cutting, your body pulls from "easy" areas first (arms, calves) and face fat last.
   463→
   464→**The Individual Factor:**
   465→Some guys have lean faces at 16%. Others need to hit 11% before the jaw pops. This is genetics—work with what you have, not against it.
   466→
   467→**The Math:**
   468→If your face doesn't lean out until 12%, and you're currently 20%, that's roughly **16 weeks of cutting** at 0.5% body fat loss per week. Set your expectations accordingly.`,
   469→      media: [
   470→        {
   471→          id: 'bf-face-progression',
   472→          type: 'image',
   473→          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1597223557154-721c1cecc4b0?w=800&q=80',
   474→          alt: 'Lean face definition example',
   475→          caption: 'The same bone structure reveals itself at lower body fat',
   476→          placement: 'inline',
   477→        },
   478→      ],
   479→    },
   480→    {
   481→      id: 'fat-loss-order',
   482→      title: 'Where Fat Disappears First (Gender Differences)',
   483→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   484→      content: `Fat loss order is largely genetic, but there are predictable patterns by gender:
   485→
   486→**Men's Fat Loss Order:**
   487→
   488→| Order | Area | When It Goes |
   489→|-------|------|--------------|
   490→| 1st | Arms, shoulders | First few weeks |
   491→| 2nd | Upper back | Early cut |
   492→| 3rd | Chest | Mid cut |
   493→| 4th | Upper abdomen | Mid-late cut |
   494→| 5th | Lower abdomen | Late cut |
   495→| 6th | Love handles | Very late |
   496→| 7th | **Face, chin** | Often LAST |
   497→
   498→Men typically store fat in the midsection (visceral) and face. The lower belly and face are usually the final bastions.
   499→
   500→**Women's Fat Loss Order:**
   501→
   502→| Order | Area | When It Goes |
   503→|-------|------|--------------|
   504→| 1st | Upper body, arms | Early |
   505→| 2nd | Back | Early-mid |
   506→| 3rd | Face | Often earlier than men |
   507→| 4th | Upper legs | Mid cut |
   508→| 5th | Hips, butt | Late |
   509→| 6th | Lower belly | Very late |
   510→| 7th | Inner thighs | Often LAST |
   511→
   512→Women store fat in hips, thighs, and butt for reproductive reasons. These areas are hormonally protected and go last.
   513→
   514→**The Implications:**
   515→- **Men:** Your face may stay soft until you're quite lean overall. Keep going.
   516→- **Women:** Your face often leans out faster, but lower body holds on longer.
   517→
   518→**Stubborn Fat Science:**
   519→"Stubborn" fat areas have more alpha-2 receptors, which resist fat release. These areas also have poor blood flow. This is why targeted fat loss ("spot reduction") doesn't work—you can't force fat cells to release based on where you exercise.
   520→
   521→The only solution is overall fat loss until you reach your stubborn areas.`,
   522→    },
   523→    {
   524→      id: 'stubborn-fat-solutions',
   525→      title: 'Stubborn Fat Solutions (When Diet Isn\'t Enough)',
   526→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   527→      content: `What if you're lean everywhere except one problem area? Here are the options:
   528→
   529→**First: Are You Actually Lean?**
   530→Be honest. Most people who think they have "stubborn fat" are just not lean enough yet. Get to 10-12% body fat (men) or 18-20% (women) before considering other options.
   531→
   532→**If You're Genuinely Lean but Have Stubborn Areas:**
   533→
   534→**Option 1: Fasted Cardio + Yohimbine (Budget)**
   535→- Fasted morning cardio can preferentially target stubborn fat
   536→- Yohimbine HCL blocks alpha-2 receptors
   537→- Take 0.2mg/kg bodyweight before fasted cardio
   538→- Must be in a fasted state (no insulin present)
   539→- Stimulant—not for everyone
   540→
   541→**Option 2: CoolSculpting / Cryolipolysis ($$$)**
   542→- Freezes and kills fat cells
   543→- 20-25% fat reduction per session
   544→- Multiple sessions needed
   545→- Cost: $600-1,200 per area
   546→- Results in 2-3 months
   547→- Non-invasive
   548→
   549→**Option 3: Kybella (Chin Fat Specifically) ($$)**
   550→- Injectable for submental fat (double chin)
   551→- Dissolves fat cells permanently
   552→- 2-4 sessions needed
   553→- Cost: $600-1,200 per session
   554→- Swelling for 1-2 weeks post-treatment
   555→
   556→**Option 4: Liposuction (Permanent, $$$$)**
   557→
   558→The nuclear option for stubborn fat. Here's what you need to know:
   559→
   560→| Factor | Details |
   561→|--------|---------|
   562→| **Best For** | Localized fat deposits that don't respond to diet |
   563→| **Common Areas** | Chin, love handles, lower abs, inner thighs |
   564→| **Cost** | $3,000-$10,000+ per area (USA) |
   565→| **Recovery** | 1-2 weeks off work, 4-6 weeks to see results |
   566→| **Results** | Permanent fat cell removal (cells can't return) |
   567→| **Caveat** | You can still gain fat in remaining cells |
   568→
   569→**Types of Liposuction:**
   570→- **Traditional:** Suction through cannula
   571→- **VASER:** Ultrasound-assisted, less bruising
   572→- **SmartLipo:** Laser-assisted, tighter skin
   573→- **AirSculpt:** Minimal downtime, premium cost
   574→
   575→**Critical Point:**
   576→Liposuction is NOT a weight loss procedure. It's for body contouring when you're already lean. If you're 20%+ body fat, diet first.
   577→
   578→**Medical Tourism:**
   579→Many people get lipo abroad at 30-60% lower cost. Popular destinations: Mexico, Turkey, Colombia. Research your surgeon thoroughly.`,
   580→      warnings: [
   581→        'Liposuction at high body fat % leads to uneven results',
   582→        'Fat can redistribute to other areas if you gain weight post-lipo',
   583→        'Always verify surgeon credentials and see real before/afters'
   584→      ],
   585→    },
   586→    {
   587→      id: 'common-mistakes',
   588→      title: 'Common Cutting Mistakes',
   589→      humorLevel: 'high',
   590→      content: `Don't be this guy:
   591→
   592→---
   593→
   594→## Mistake 1: Cutting Too Fast
   595→
   596→*"I'll just eat 1200 calories and do 2 hours of cardio."*
   597→
   598→**Result:** Lose muscle, crash metabolism, binge, end up fatter than before.
   599→
   600→---
   601→
   602→## Mistake 2: Ignoring Protein
   603→
   604→*"I'm just not going to eat much."*
   605→
   606→**Result:** Skinny-fat physique, lost the muscle, kept the face fat.
   607→
   608→---
   609→
   610→## Mistake 3: Weekend Cheats
   611→
   612→*"I was good all week!"*
   613→
   614→**Result:** 3500 calorie surplus Saturday-Sunday wipes out the weekly deficit.
   615→
   616→---
   617→
   618→## Mistake 4: Drinking Calories
   619→
   620→*"But it's just juice/beer/coffee drinks."*
   621→
   622→**Result:** 500+ invisible calories daily, no satiety, confused why scale won't move.
   623→
   624→---
   625→
   626→## Mistake 5: No Resistance Training
   627→
   628→*"I just need to do cardio to lose weight."*
   629→
   630→**Result:** Lost 20 lbs—15 of muscle. Now you're a smaller, softer version of yourself.
   631→
   632→---
   633→
   634→## Mistake 6: Obsessing Over the Scale
   635→
   636→*"I gained 2 lbs overnight, I'm done!"*
   637→
   638→**Result:** Water fluctuation caused a mental breakdown. Real progress lost in the noise.
   639→
   640→---
   641→
   642→Avoid these and you're ahead of 90% of people trying to cut.`,
   643→    },
   644→    {
   645→      id: 'action-plan',
   646→      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   647→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   648→      content: `Here's exactly what to do:
   649→
   650→---
   651→
   652→## Step 1: Establish Baseline
   653→
   654→- Get a DEXA scan or estimate body fat from photos
   655→- Calculate TDEE (plenty of calculators online)
   656→- Take photos in consistent lighting
   657→
   658→## Step 2: Set Up Tracking
   659→
   660→- Download a calorie tracking app
   661→- Get a food scale (non-negotiable for accuracy)
   662→- Set protein and calorie targets
   663→
   664→## Step 3: Start the Cut
   665→
   666→- 300-500 calorie deficit
   667→- Hit protein daily (0.8-1g/lb)
   668→- Lift weights 3-4x per week (don't just do cardio)
   669→
   670→## Step 4: Monitor and Adjust
   671→
   672→- Weigh daily, average weekly
   673→- If not losing after 2 weeks, reduce by 100-200 calories
   674→- Take weekly photos in same conditions
   675→
   676→## Step 5: Be Patient
   677→
   678→- Expect 10-15 weeks for a significant cut
   679→- Facial changes come last—don't quit early
   680→- Adjust timeline based on actual progress
   681→
   682→---
   683→
   684→## Your face will thank you. Lock in.`,
   685→      products: ['food_scale'],
   686→    },
   687→  ],
   688→};

/**
 * Body Fat Mastery Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium-High (20%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const bodyFatGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'body-fat',
  slug: 'body-fat-mastery',
  title: 'Body Fat Mastery',
  subtitle: "Your jawline is in there somewhere—go find it",
  description: "The single biggest lever for facial aesthetics. Going from 18% to 12% body fat transforms your face.",
  icon: 'TrendingDown',
  humorLevel: 'medium-high',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 3,
  tags: ['body-fat', 'cutting', 'diet', 'facial-aesthetics'],
  relatedGuides: ['diet', 'v-taper', 'training'],
  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono'],
  forumCategory: 'face-fat',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'bodyfat-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019613454-1cb2f99b2d8b?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Body fat transformation showing facial definition improvement',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Truth About Body Fat and Your Face',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `At 18% body fat, you're hoping good lighting saves you. At 11%, you ARE the good lighting.

Here's the brutal truth: you can have god-tier bone structure, but if it's buried under a layer of subcutaneous fat, you're frauding yourself out of your own genetics.

---

## Lean is life. Your jawline knows it.

This isn't about being skinny. It's about being lean enough that your facial features actually show:

- **Jawline definition** — The #1 facial aesthetic improvement
- **Cheekbone projection** — Creates that hollow, chiseled look
- **Under-eye area** — No puffy fat pads
- **Neck/chin separation** — Clean, sharp profile

Most guys have never seen their own bone structure because they've never been lean enough.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'face-fat-comparison',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1583454110551-21f2fa2afe61?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Lean athletic physique showing definition',
          caption: 'The same bone structure at 18% vs 12% body fat',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'bf-ranges',
      title: 'Body Fat Percentage Breakdown',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's be honest about what each range actually looks like:

| Body Fat % | What You See | Face Impact |
|------------|--------------|-------------|
| **20%+** | Soft everywhere, no definition | Buried jaw, soft cheeks, possible double chin |
| **17-20%** | Some definition in good lighting | Jaw visible but soft, face holds water |
| **14-17%** | Visible abs in good lighting | Decent definition, not optimal |
| **12-14%** | Abs visible standing | Good facial definition, jaw pops |
| **10-12%** | Clear 6-pack, veins showing | Excellent definition, cheekbones visible |
| **8-10%** | Shredded, stage-ready | Maximum facial definition |
| **<8%** | Competition lean | Hard to maintain, not realistic long-term |

---

## The Sweet Spot: 10-14%

This is where you're lean enough for facial definition but not so lean that you're constantly hungry, weak, and irritable.

Most guys should aim for this range.

Below 10% is diminishing returns unless you're competing or doing a photoshoot.`,
      tips: [
        'Take photos in neutral lighting to assess—bathroom mirror lighting lies',
        'Measure waist circumference as a simple tracking metric',
        'DEXA scans are the gold standard for accuracy',
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bf-visual-guide',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://www.builtlean.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/body-fat-percentage-men-759x1024.jpg',
          alt: 'Male body fat percentage visual comparison chart',
          caption: 'Visual guide: What each body fat percentage actually looks like',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'where-fat-stores',
      title: 'Where Fat Stores (And Why Your Face Suffers)',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Fat distribution is genetic, but there's a general pattern:

---

## First to Store (Last to Lose)

These are the stubborn areas:

- Lower belly
- Love handles
- Lower back
- **Face (buccal area, under chin)**

## Last to Store (First to Lose)

These lean out quickly:

- Arms
- Upper chest
- Calves

---

## What This Means

Your face is often one of the **LAST** places to lean out.

This is why guys at 18% think *"I'm not even that fat"* while their jaw is still buried.

## The Face Tax

If you carry fat in your face (many people do), you might need to get leaner than average to see facial definition.

Someone might have a visible 6-pack at 14%, but their face doesn't pop until 11%.

It's not fair. It's genetics. Work with it.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'fat-distribution',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019614242-c5c5dee9f50b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete with lean physique',
          caption: 'Common fat storage patterns - face fat is often the last to go',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'measuring',
      title: 'How to Actually Measure Body Fat',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most methods are garbage. Here's the hierarchy:

---

## Tier 1: DEXA Scan (Most Accurate)

- $50-150 at clinics
- Tells you exactly where fat is distributed
- Worth getting once to establish baseline

## Tier 2: Calipers (Decent If Done Right)

- $15 for calipers
- 7-site measurement protocol
- Requires practice and consistency
- ±3% error margin

## Tier 3: Navy Method (Free, Okay)

- Uses neck and waist measurements
- Formula-based estimate
- Better than nothing

## Tier 4: Bioelectrical Impedance (Mostly Useless)

- Those scales and gym machines
- Varies wildly based on hydration
- Can be off by 5-10%
- Only useful for tracking trends, not absolute numbers

## Tier 5: Mirror + Photos (Subjective But Real)

- Compare to reference photos at known body fat %
- Track progress over time
- Lighting consistent, same time of day

---

**Recommendation:** Get a DEXA scan once, then track via photos and waist measurement.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-math',
      title: 'The Fat Loss Equation',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `This is simple math. Not easy, but simple.

---

## The Formula

> **Calories In < Calories Out = Fat Loss**

That's it. There's no metabolic magic. No foods that "burn fat." No supplements that override physics.

---

## Setting Your Deficit

1. Calculate maintenance calories (TDEE)
2. Subtract 300-500 calories
3. Adjust based on results

## Rate of Loss

| Goal | Rate | Weekly Deficit |
|------|------|----------------|
| **Sustainable** | 0.5-1% of bodyweight/week | 300-500 cal/day |
| **Aggressive** | 1-1.5% of bodyweight/week | 500-750 cal/day |
| **Too Fast** | >1.5% of bodyweight/week | Muscle loss risk |

---

## For a 180lb guy:

- **Target:** 0.9-1.8 lbs per week
- **Deficit:** 450-900 calories daily
- **Timeline:** 10 lbs of fat takes 5-10 weeks minimum

**The Reality:** Most guys try to cut too fast, lose muscle, feel like death, and rebound. Don't be that guy.`,
      tips: [
        '500 calorie deficit = ~1 lb fat loss per week',
        'Weigh daily, average weekly (weight fluctuates)',
        "If you're not losing, you're eating more than you think",
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'protein-priority',
      title: 'Protein: The Non-Negotiable',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `When cutting, protein is king. Everything else is secondary.

---

## Why Protein Matters

- **Preserves muscle mass** during deficit
- **Most satiating** macronutrient (keeps you full)
- **Highest thermic effect** (burns calories to digest)
- **Prevents** the "skinny fat" look

## How Much

| Bodyweight | Daily Protein Target |
|------------|---------------------|
| 150 lbs | 120-150g |
| 180 lbs | 144-180g |
| 200 lbs | 160-200g |
| 220 lbs | 176-220g |

Yes, this seems like a lot. Yes, it's necessary.

---

## Example Day (180g protein)

| Meal | Foods | Protein |
|------|-------|---------|
| **Breakfast** | 4 eggs + greek yogurt | 40g |
| **Lunch** | 8oz chicken breast + cottage cheese | 60g |
| **Dinner** | 8oz salmon + protein shake | 60g |
| **Snack** | Protein bar | 20g |
| **TOTAL** | | **180g** |

If you're consistently under on protein, you're going to lose muscle and end up looking worse at the same weight.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono'],
    },
    {
      id: 'water-and-bloat',
      title: 'Water Weight and Facial Bloat',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're not drinking enough water. Yes, you.

Your face is literally retaining fluid to compensate.

---

## The Paradox

> Drink **MORE** water to hold **LESS** water.

Your body retains fluid when dehydrated.

## The Protocol

| Bodyweight | Daily Water Target |
|------------|-------------------|
| 150 lbs | 75 oz (2.2L) |
| 180 lbs | 90 oz (2.7L) |
| 200 lbs | 100 oz (3L) |
| 220 lbs | 110 oz (3.3L) |

Add more if training or sweating.

---

## What Causes Facial Bloat

| Cause | Effect | Fix |
|-------|--------|-----|
| **Sodium** | High salt = water retention | Keep moderate, not zero |
| **Alcohol** | Dehydrates, then overcompensates | Limit or eliminate |
| **Carbs** | Each gram stores 3-4g of water | Expected, not bad |
| **Sleep deprivation** | Cortisol = water retention | Get 7-8 hours |
| **Dehydration** | Counter-intuitive but true | Drink more water |

---

## The Morning Difference

Ever notice you look leaner in the morning?

You're slightly dehydrated after 8 hours without water. This is why fighters cut water weight—it makes a visible difference.

For consistent leanness, stay consistently hydrated and keep sodium moderate.`,
      products: ['water_jug'],
      tips: [
        'Drink a full glass of water immediately upon waking',
        'Cut sodium 24-48 hours before photos for temporary tightness',
        "Alcohol is the worst for next-day face bloat",
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bloat-comparison',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1548690312-e3b507d8c110?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Healthy hydration and fitness',
          caption: 'Same person: bloated vs properly hydrated',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'timeline',
      title: 'Realistic Cutting Timeline',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's set realistic expectations:

---

## Starting Point: 20% Body Fat (180lb guy)

- **Goal:** 12% body fat
- **Fat to lose:** ~15 lbs
- **Timeline:** 10-15 weeks (doing it right)

---

## Week by Week Progress

| Weeks | What Happens | What You See |
|-------|--------------|--------------|
| **1-2** | Water weight drops | Scale moves fast, exciting |
| **3-6** | Steady fat loss | Starting to see changes |
| **7-10** | Face starts tightening | Jaw appearing, cheekbones hint |
| **11-15** | Final stubborn fat burns | Face pops, transformation complete |

---

## The Trap

Weeks 6-10 are where most guys quit.

Scale slows, you don't see daily changes, and pizza sounds really good.

## The Reality

> Fat loss in the face often happens in the **final phase**.

You might look the same for weeks, then suddenly *"damn, there's my jawline."*

Be patient. Trust the deficit. Don't quit in the middle of the transformation.`,
      warnings: [
        "Don't cut harder because the scale slowed—you'll lose muscle",
        'Take weekly photos in the same conditions for accurate comparison',
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'timeline-progress',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1517836357463-d25dfeac3438?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Visual timeline of fitness progress',
          caption: '12-week transformation: patience is key',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'maintaining',
      title: 'Maintaining Lean (The Hard Part)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Getting lean is one thing. Staying lean is another.

---

## Why Maintenance Is Hard

- Hunger hormones increase after cutting
- Metabolism adapts (slightly) to lower calories
- One vacation can undo weeks of progress
- Life happens

## The Strategy

1. **Reverse diet** — Slowly increase calories after cutting
2. **Stay active** — NEAT (daily movement) matters as much as gym
3. **Keep tracking** — At least loosely, forever
4. **Set a ceiling** — "I never go above 15%" as a rule

---

## The Buffer Zone

Cutting to 11% then maintaining at 13% is easier than trying to stay at 11% year-round.

Give yourself a 2-3% buffer for life fluctuations.

## The Long Game

> Most guys yo-yo because they treat cutting as temporary.

Make leanness part of your identity, not a phase.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'face-fat-timeline',
      title: 'Face Fat Timeline by Body Fat %',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `When does the face actually lean out? Here's the brutal truth by body fat percentage:

**The Face Fat Timeline:**

| Body Fat % | Face Status | What You See |
|------------|-------------|--------------|
| **25%+** | Maximum bloat | Round face, double chin likely, jaw completely hidden |
| **22-25%** | Soft face | Face is round, no definition, chipmunk mode |
| **18-22%** | Still soft | Jaw exists but is soft, some face fat visible |
| **15-18%** | Improving | Jaw becoming defined, some cheek fat remaining |
| **12-15%** | Good definition | Jaw pops, cheekbones starting to show, face leaning out |
| **10-12%** | Excellent | Hollow cheeks appearing, strong jaw, model tier face |
| **8-10%** | Maximum definition | Chiseled, veins in face possible, not sustainable |

**The Critical Threshold:**
For most men, facial definition really kicks in between **12-15%**. If you're 18% and wondering why your face still looks soft despite visible abs in good lighting—this is why.

**Why Your Face Is Last:**
Your body prioritizes fat storage in the face and midsection for protection and hormone regulation. These are the "safe" areas to store reserves. When cutting, your body pulls from "easy" areas first (arms, calves) and face fat last.

**The Individual Factor:**
Some guys have lean faces at 16%. Others need to hit 11% before the jaw pops. This is genetics—work with what you have, not against it.

**The Math:**
If your face doesn't lean out until 12%, and you're currently 20%, that's roughly **16 weeks of cutting** at 0.5% body fat loss per week. Set your expectations accordingly.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bf-face-progression',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1597223557154-721c1cecc4b0?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Lean face definition example',
          caption: 'The same bone structure reveals itself at lower body fat',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fat-loss-order',
      title: 'Where Fat Disappears First (Gender Differences)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Fat loss order is largely genetic, but there are predictable patterns by gender:

**Men's Fat Loss Order:**

| Order | Area | When It Goes |
|-------|------|--------------|
| 1st | Arms, shoulders | First few weeks |
| 2nd | Upper back | Early cut |
| 3rd | Chest | Mid cut |
| 4th | Upper abdomen | Mid-late cut |
| 5th | Lower abdomen | Late cut |
| 6th | Love handles | Very late |
| 7th | **Face, chin** | Often LAST |

Men typically store fat in the midsection (visceral) and face. The lower belly and face are usually the final bastions.

**Women's Fat Loss Order:**

| Order | Area | When It Goes |
|-------|------|--------------|
| 1st | Upper body, arms | Early |
| 2nd | Back | Early-mid |
| 3rd | Face | Often earlier than men |
| 4th | Upper legs | Mid cut |
| 5th | Hips, butt | Late |
| 6th | Lower belly | Very late |
| 7th | Inner thighs | Often LAST |

Women store fat in hips, thighs, and butt for reproductive reasons. These areas are hormonally protected and go last.

**The Implications:**
- **Men:** Your face may stay soft until you're quite lean overall. Keep going.
- **Women:** Your face often leans out faster, but lower body holds on longer.

**Stubborn Fat Science:**
"Stubborn" fat areas have more alpha-2 receptors, which resist fat release. These areas also have poor blood flow. This is why targeted fat loss ("spot reduction") doesn't work—you can't force fat cells to release based on where you exercise.

The only solution is overall fat loss until you reach your stubborn areas.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'stubborn-fat-solutions',
      title: 'Stubborn Fat Solutions (When Diet Isn\'t Enough)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `What if you're lean everywhere except one problem area? Here are the options:

**First: Are You Actually Lean?**
Be honest. Most people who think they have "stubborn fat" are just not lean enough yet. Get to 10-12% body fat (men) or 18-20% (women) before considering other options.

**If You're Genuinely Lean but Have Stubborn Areas:**

**Option 1: Fasted Cardio + Yohimbine (Budget)**
- Fasted morning cardio can preferentially target stubborn fat
- Yohimbine HCL blocks alpha-2 receptors
- Take 0.2mg/kg bodyweight before fasted cardio
- Must be in a fasted state (no insulin present)
- Stimulant—not for everyone

**Option 2: CoolSculpting / Cryolipolysis ($$$)**
- Freezes and kills fat cells
- 20-25% fat reduction per session
- Multiple sessions needed
- Cost: $600-1,200 per area
- Results in 2-3 months
- Non-invasive

**Option 3: Kybella (Chin Fat Specifically) ($$)**
- Injectable for submental fat (double chin)
- Dissolves fat cells permanently
- 2-4 sessions needed
- Cost: $600-1,200 per session
- Swelling for 1-2 weeks post-treatment

**Option 4: Liposuction (Permanent, $$$$)**

The nuclear option for stubborn fat. Here's what you need to know:

| Factor | Details |
|--------|---------|
| **Best For** | Localized fat deposits that don't respond to diet |
| **Common Areas** | Chin, love handles, lower abs, inner thighs |
| **Cost** | $3,000-$10,000+ per area (USA) |
| **Recovery** | 1-2 weeks off work, 4-6 weeks to see results |
| **Results** | Permanent fat cell removal (cells can't return) |
| **Caveat** | You can still gain fat in remaining cells |

**Types of Liposuction:**
- **Traditional:** Suction through cannula
- **VASER:** Ultrasound-assisted, less bruising
- **SmartLipo:** Laser-assisted, tighter skin
- **AirSculpt:** Minimal downtime, premium cost

**Critical Point:**
Liposuction is NOT a weight loss procedure. It's for body contouring when you're already lean. If you're 20%+ body fat, diet first.

**Medical Tourism:**
Many people get lipo abroad at 30-60% lower cost. Popular destinations: Mexico, Turkey, Colombia. Research your surgeon thoroughly.`,
      warnings: [
        'Liposuction at high body fat % leads to uneven results',
        'Fat can redistribute to other areas if you gain weight post-lipo',
        'Always verify surgeon credentials and see real before/afters'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'common-mistakes',
      title: 'Common Cutting Mistakes',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Don't be this guy:

---

## Mistake 1: Cutting Too Fast

*"I'll just eat 1200 calories and do 2 hours of cardio."*

**Result:** Lose muscle, crash metabolism, binge, end up fatter than before.

---

## Mistake 2: Ignoring Protein

*"I'm just not going to eat much."*

**Result:** Skinny-fat physique, lost the muscle, kept the face fat.

---

## Mistake 3: Weekend Cheats

*"I was good all week!"*

**Result:** 3500 calorie surplus Saturday-Sunday wipes out the weekly deficit.

---

## Mistake 4: Drinking Calories

*"But it's just juice/beer/coffee drinks."*

**Result:** 500+ invisible calories daily, no satiety, confused why scale won't move.

---

## Mistake 5: No Resistance Training

*"I just need to do cardio to lose weight."*

**Result:** Lost 20 lbs—15 of muscle. Now you're a smaller, softer version of yourself.

---

## Mistake 6: Obsessing Over the Scale

*"I gained 2 lbs overnight, I'm done!"*

**Result:** Water fluctuation caused a mental breakdown. Real progress lost in the noise.

---

Avoid these and you're ahead of 90% of people trying to cut.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's exactly what to do:

---

## Step 1: Establish Baseline

- Get a DEXA scan or estimate body fat from photos
- Calculate TDEE (plenty of calculators online)
- Take photos in consistent lighting

## Step 2: Set Up Tracking

- Download a calorie tracking app
- Get a food scale (non-negotiable for accuracy)
- Set protein and calorie targets

## Step 3: Start the Cut

- 300-500 calorie deficit
- Hit protein daily (0.8-1g/lb)
- Lift weights 3-4x per week (don't just do cardio)

## Step 4: Monitor and Adjust

- Weigh daily, average weekly
- If not losing after 2 weeks, reduce by 100-200 calories
- Take weekly photos in same conditions

## Step 5: Be Patient

- Expect 10-15 weeks for a significant cut
- Facial changes come last—don't quit early
- Adjust timeline based on actual progress

---

## Your face will thank you. Lock in.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
    },
  ],
};

   380→
   381→**Mistake 3: All Chest, No Back**

   383→

   385→Weighted side bends, wood chops with too much resistance. Congrats, you just widened your waist.
   386→
   387→**Mistake 5: Bulking Too Hard**
   388→"I need to eat big to get big." Now your waist is 36 inches and your V-taper is gone. Stay relatively lean while building.
   389→
   390→**Mistake 6: Not Training Rear Delts**
   391→Shoulders look flat from the side. Rotator cuff injuries from pressing imbalance. Easily prevented, commonly neglected.`,
   392→    },
   393→    {
   394→      id: 'action-steps',
   395→      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   396→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   397→      content: `Start building your V-taper today:
   398→
   399→**Immediate Actions:**
   400→1. Add lateral raises to every upper body day (minimum 3x per week)
   401→2. Add face pulls for rear delts (minimum 2x per week)
   402→3. Prioritize pull-ups or lat pulldowns for width
   403→
   404→**Weekly Volume Targets:**
   405→- Side Delts: 12-16 sets per week
   406→- Rear Delts: 8-12 sets per week
   407→- Lats: 10-15 sets per week (vertical + horizontal)
   408→
   409→**Waist Management:**
   410→- Practice stomach vacuums daily
   411→- Avoid heavy weighted oblique work
   412→- Stay in the 10-14% body fat range
   413→
   414→**Tracking:**
   415→- Measure shoulder and waist circumference monthly
   416→- Take progress photos (back and side views)
   417→- Track your lifting numbers for progressive overload
   418→
   419→**Supplementation:**
   420→- Creatine for strength and fullness
   421→- Protein for muscle building
   422→- That's it—no magic pills for width
   423→
   424→The V-taper is earned, not given. Start building it now.`,
   425→      products: ['creatine_mono', 'collagen_peptides'],
   426→    },
   427→  ],
   428→};

/**
 * V-Taper Building Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const vTaperGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'v-taper',
  slug: 'v-taper-building',
  title: 'V-Taper Building',
  subtitle: "Shoulder-to-waist ratio that makes shirts fit different",
  description: "Build the classic V-shape physique that signals athleticism and dominance. Wide shoulders, narrow waist.",
  icon: 'Dumbbell',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 10,
  order: 4,
  tags: ['physique', 'shoulders', 'back', 'v-taper', 'aesthetics'],
  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'diet'],
  productIds: ['creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'collagen_peptides'],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'v-taper-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1583454110551-21f2fa2afe61?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Classic V-taper physique - wide shoulders, narrow waist',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'What Is the V-Taper?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The V-taper is the ratio between your shoulder width and your waist circumference. It's one of the most universally attractive physical traits and signals:
- Athleticism
- Testosterone
- Physical capability

**The Golden Ratio:**
Your shoulder circumference should be roughly 1.618x your waist circumference. This is the mathematical proportion that's been considered ideal since ancient Greece.

**The Reality:**
Most guys have the opposite—narrow shoulders and wide waists. This is what sitting at a desk 8 hours a day produces.

**The Fix:**
Build the shoulders and lats wide. Keep the waist narrow. Simple concept, requires consistent work.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'v-taper-transformation',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://outlift.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/09/v-taper-physique.jpg',
          alt: 'V-taper physique before and after transformation',
          caption: 'The V-taper transformation: narrow shoulders to wide, wide waist to narrow',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'anatomy',
      title: 'The Muscles That Create Width',
      humorLevel: 'low',
      content: `Understanding which muscles create visual width is crucial for training priorities:

**Primary Width Builders:**

1. **Lateral Deltoids (Side Delts)**
   - Create the "capped" shoulder look
   - Most undertrained muscle for width
   - Need direct isolation work

2. **Latissimus Dorsi (Lats)**
   - The "wings" that create width from behind
   - Pull your arms down and back
   - Best hit with vertical and horizontal pulls

3. **Rear Deltoids**
   - Often neglected, visible from side and back
   - Balance the shoulder appearance
   - Prevent injury from pressing imbalances

**Secondary Considerations:**

4. **Upper Chest**
   - Fills out the upper frame
   - Creates the "armor plate" look

5. **Traps (Upper Back)**
   - Add thickness and presence
   - Don't overtrain—can shorten neck appearance

**The Waist:**
The taper is relative. A 30-inch waist looks wider with 44-inch shoulders than 48-inch. Keeping the waist tight through diet and core stability is half the equation.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'side-delts',
      title: 'Lateral Deltoid Priority',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Side delts are the #1 underdeveloped muscle for V-taper. Period.

**Why They're Stubborn:**
- Small muscle group
- Often trained wrong (momentum, too heavy)
- Need high volume and frequency
- Front delts take over in most pressing movements

**The Exercises:**
1. **Lateral Raises** — The staple. Light weight, controlled, feel the burn
2. **Cable Lateral Raises** — Constant tension, superior mind-muscle connection
3. **Machine Lateral Raises** — Fixed path, can go heavier safely
4. **Behind-the-Back Cable Raises** — Hits the side head differently

**Programming:**
- Hit side delts 3-4x per week (they recover fast)
- 3-4 sets of 15-20 reps (they respond to volume)
- Focus on the stretch and contraction, not the weight
- Ego lifting on lateral raises is the biggest mistake

**The Feel:**
If you're not feeling it in your side delts, you're doing it wrong. Lighten the weight, slow down, and focus on lifting with your elbows, not your hands.`,
      tips: [
        'Lead with elbows, not hands',
        'Slight forward lean isolates side delt better',
        "If you can't do 15 controlled reps, it's too heavy"
      ],
    },
    {

      title: 'Lat Width Development',

      content: `Big lats = wide back = visual dominance. When you walk into a room, lats are what make people move.

**Vertical Pulls (Width Focus):**

**Horizontal Pulls (Thickness + Width):**

2. **Dumbbell Rows** — Great stretch, unilateral work
3. **Seated Cable Rows** — Constant tension, controlled

**Programming:**
- 2-3 vertical pulls per week
- 2-3 horizontal pulls per week
- 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps
- Focus on the stretch at the bottom, squeeze at the top

**The Mind-Muscle Connection:**
Most guys turn back exercises into arm exercises. Think about pulling your elbows DOWN and BACK, not pulling the weight to you. Your hands are just hooks.`,

      title: 'Rear Delt Training',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Rear delts are invisible in the mirror but critical for:
- Balanced shoulder development
- Injury prevention
- That 3D shoulder look from the side

**The Problem:**
Nobody sees their rear delts, so nobody trains them. Then they wonder why their shoulders look flat from the side and why their shoulders hurt from pressing.

**The Exercises:**
1. **Face Pulls** — Best overall rear delt exercise
2. **Reverse Pec Deck** — Easy isolation
3. **Bent Over Rear Delt Raises** — Requires strict form
4. **Cable Rear Delt Flies** — Constant tension variation

**Programming:**
- 2-3x per week
- 3-4 sets of 15-20 reps
- Light weight, high control
- Can superset with side delt work

**Face Pull Form:**
Pull to forehead, not to neck. External rotation at the top. Hold the squeeze for 1-2 seconds. If you're going heavy and using momentum, you're working your traps, not rear delts.`,

      content: `The other half of the V-taper equation: a small waist. You can have massive shoulders, but if your waist is wide, the ratio is lost.

**What Widens the Waist:**
- Body fat (especially visceral fat)
- Overdeveloped obliques (heavy side bends)
- Bloating and poor posture
- Thick lower back from deadlifts (slightly)

**What Keeps It Tight:**
- Low body fat (10-14%)
- Stomach vacuums (transverse abdominis training)
- Limiting heavy oblique work
- Good posture (prevents belly pooch)

**The Vacuum Exercise:**
This is the classic bodybuilding trick for waist control:
1. Exhale all air
2. Suck stomach in as far as possible
3. Hold for 15-30 seconds
4. Repeat 5-10 times
5. Do daily, ideally in the morning on empty stomach

**The Note on Obliques:**
You don't need to train them directly. They get worked in compound movements. Heavy weighted side bends can actually widen your waist—the opposite of what you want.`,

**Day 2: Pull (Lat Width Focus)**
- Pull-Ups: 4x8-12
- Barbell Rows: 4x8-10
- Lat Pulldowns: 3x10-12
- Face Pulls: 4x15-20
- Rear Delt Flies: 3x15-20

**Day 3: Legs**
- Squats: 4x6-8
- Romanian Deadlifts: 3x10-12
- Leg Press: 3x12-15
- Leg Curls: 3x12-15
- Calf Raises: 4x15-20

**Day 4: Push (Chest Focus)**

**Month 1-3: Foundation**

**Month 4-6: Visible Progress**

**Month 7-12: Real Development**
- Clear V-taper in the mirror

**Year 2+: Advanced Development**

**Why Women Should Train for Width:**
- Creates the hourglass illusion
- Makes waist look smaller by comparison
- Improves posture and presence
- Balanced physique > skinny-fat

**The Female Aesthetic Goal:**
Instead of "V-shape," think "X-shape"—developed shoulders AND developed glutes with a tight waist in the middle.

**Key Differences from Male Training:**

| Aspect | Men | Women |
|--------|-----|-------|
| **Goal** | Wide shoulders, narrow waist | Shoulders + glutes, small waist |
| **Shoulder development** | Maximum width | Moderate width, cap shape |
| **Lat development** | Maximum width | Moderate—avoid "too wide" look |
| **Trap development** | Can go heavy | Keep minimal (can look masculine) |

**Female V-Taper Priorities:**

**1. Capped Shoulders (Not Massive)**

**2. Lat Development (Moderate)**
- Pull-ups/lat pulldowns: 3-4 sets of 8-12 reps
- Creates the taper from armpit to waist
- Don't go too wide—you're not trying to look like a bodybuilder

**3. Rear Delts (Essential)**
- Face pulls and reverse flies

- Creates 3D shoulder look from side

**4. Waist Management:**
- Stomach vacuums (same as men)

**5. Glute Development (The Other Half):**

**Sample Female V-Taper Day:**

      content: `Don't sabotage your width:

**Mistake 1: Neglecting Side Delts**
Front delts get hit in every press. Side delts don't. If you're not doing direct lateral work, you're not building width.

**Mistake 2: Going Too Heavy on Lateral Raises**
Ego lifting with 40lb dumbbells and full body momentum. Your side delts never feel it. Drop to 15lbs and actually control the movement.

**Mistake 3: All Chest, No Back**
Mirror muscles syndrome. You can't see your back, so you don't train it. Result: narrow, hunched, imbalanced.

**Mistake 4: Heavy Oblique Work**
Weighted side bends, wood chops with too much resistance. Congrats, you just widened your waist.

**Mistake 5: Bulking Too Hard**
"I need to eat big to get big." Now your waist is 36 inches and your V-taper is gone. Stay relatively lean while building.

**Mistake 6: Not Training Rear Delts**
Shoulders look flat from the side. Rotator cuff injuries from pressing imbalance. Easily prevented, commonly neglected.`,

- Side Delts: 12-16 sets per week
- Rear Delts: 8-12 sets per week
- Lats: 10-15 sets per week (vertical + horizontal)

**Waist Management:**
- Practice stomach vacuums daily
- Avoid heavy weighted oblique work
- Stay in the 10-14% body fat range

**Tracking:**
- Measure shoulder and waist circumference monthly
- Take progress photos (back and side views)
- Track your lifting numbers for progressive overload

**Supplementation:**
- Creatine for strength and fullness
- Protein for muscle building
- That's it—no magic pills for width

The V-taper is earned, not given. Start building it now.`,

   369→          id: 'tretinoin-timeline',
   370→          type: 'image',

   372→          alt: 'Skincare progress and results',
   373→          caption: 'Expect 3-6 months for initial improvement, 12+ for full results',

   376→      ],
   377→    },
   378→    {
   379→      id: 'skin-type',
   380→      title: 'Know Your Skin Type',
   381→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   382→      content: `Your skin type determines product selection.
   383→
   384→**Oily Skin:**
   385→- Shiny by midday
   386→- Visible pores

   390→**Dry Skin:**

   399→- Most common type

   401→
   402→**Sensitive Skin:**
   403→- Reacts easily to products
   404→- Redness, stinging
   405→- Needs: Fragrance-free, minimal ingredients, patch testing
   406→
   407→**Normal Skin:**
   408→- Balanced
   409→- Few issues
   410→- Needs: Basic maintenance
   411→
   412→**How to Test:**
   413→1. Wash face, wait 30 minutes
   414→2. Don't apply anything
   415→3. Observe how skin feels and looks
   416→
   417→If shiny → oily
   418→If tight → dry
   419→If both → combination
   420→If irritated → sensitive
   421→If fine → normal`,
   422→    },
   423→    {
   424→      id: 'acne-scarring',
   425→      title: 'Acne Scars: What Actually Works',
   426→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   427→      content: `Once acne is controlled, scars may remain. Here's what helps:
   428→
   429→**Types of Acne Scars:**
   430→- **Icepick:** Deep, narrow, V-shaped
   431→- **Boxcar:** Wide, box-like depressions
   432→- **Rolling:** Wave-like, uneven surface
   433→- **Hyperpigmentation:** Dark marks (not true scars)
   434→
   435→**What Actually Works:**
   436→
   437→**For Hyperpigmentation (Dark Marks):**
   438→- Time (fades naturally in 3-12 months)
   439→- Tretinoin (speeds fading)
   440→- Vitamin C (morning antioxidant)
   441→- Niacinamide (in moisturizer)
   442→- Sunscreen (prevents darkening)
   443→
   444→**For True Scars (Texture):**
   445→- Tretinoin (mild improvement over years)
   446→- Microneedling (professional, 4-6 sessions)
   447→- Chemical peels (professional, multiple sessions)
   448→- Laser resurfacing (fractional CO2 or Fraxel)
   449→- Subcision (for tethered scars)
   450→- TCA Cross (for icepick scars)
   451→
   452→**The Reality:**
   453→- OTC products can't fix true textural scars
   454→- Professional treatments are needed
   455→- Multiple sessions required
   456→- Results are improvement, not perfection
   457→- Cost: $200-500+ per session
   458→
   459→**Priority:**
   460→1. Get acne under control first (stop creating new scars)
   461→2. Wait for active breakouts to clear
   462→3. Then address scarring`,
   463→    },
   464→    {
   465→      id: 'lifestyle-factors',
   466→      title: 'Lifestyle Factors for Clear Skin',
   467→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   468→      content: `Your routine matters, but so does everything else:
   469→
   470→**Sleep:**
   471→- 7-9 hours for skin repair
   472→- Poor sleep = inflammation = worse skin
   473→- Sleep on clean pillowcases (change 2x/week)
   474→- Silk pillowcase reduces friction
   475→
   476→**Diet:**
   477→- High glycemic foods may worsen acne
   478→- Dairy is problematic for some people
   479→- Stay hydrated (not magic, but helps)
   480→- Omega-3s (anti-inflammatory)
   481→
   482→**Stress:**
   483→- Cortisol triggers oil production
   484→- Stress acne is real
   485→- Manage what you can
   486→
   487→**Habits:**
   488→- Don't touch your face
   489→- Clean your phone
   490→- Wash pillowcases
   491→- Don't pick at skin
   492→- Remove makeup before bed
   493→
   494→**Gym:**

   498→- Don't use dirty towels on face
   499→
   500→**Sun:**

   502→- But UV damage is worse long-term
   503→- Use sunscreen anyway`,
   504→    },
   505→    {
   506→      id: 'routine-by-goal',
   507→      title: 'Routines by Goal',
   508→      humorLevel: 'medium',
   509→      content: `Customize based on your primary concern:
   510→
   511→**Goal: Basic Maintenance (No Issues)**
   512→- AM: Rinse, moisturize, sunscreen
   513→- PM: Cleanse, moisturize
   514→
   515→**Goal: Acne Control**
   516→- AM: Cleanse, moisturize, sunscreen

   518→
   519→**Goal: Anti-Aging**
   520→- AM: Cleanse, vitamin C serum, moisturize, sunscreen
